Appendix 1: Equality Impact Assessment Form
Purpose
The purpose is to provide medical and midwifery staff with guidance
regarding their responsibilities during handover of care whilst working within Maternity Services at Mid Essex Hospitals Services NHS Trust.
Effective communication is recognised as central to promoting patient safety and reducing the number of serious clinical incidents.

An effective working relationship between the multi-disciplinary team and a clear organisational structure for midwives and medical staff with explicit and transparent lines of communication is crucial to ensure optimum care for mothers and their babies.
To ensure every patient receives continuing assessment and support throughout the antenatal, intrapartum and postnatal period.
This guideline is to be read in conjunction with the ‘Roles and responsibilities of medical and midwifery staff working within the maternity services'; register number 04227.
Equality Impact Assessment
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to Appendix A)
Role of the Midwife in Relation to the Handover of Care
There should be a personal handover of care between midwives at every change of shift or change of carer. This must be documented in the patient's maternity records each time a change has occurred.
This will include:
Each shift change of staff
Temporary relief such as breaks
The appropriate documentation should be completed following the transfer of a patient and baby
(Refer to points 7.0, 8.0, 9.0 and 10.0)

The handover tool for each area is based on SBAR – situation, background, assessment and recommendation. This tool should be used for the transfer of patients between wards i.e. antenatal, labour, postnatal and midwife-led units.
Role of the Obstetrician and the Anaesthetist in Relation to the Handover of Care

For the obstetric consultant, registrar and senior house officer (SHO) shift cover, and anaesthetic consultant and registrar shift cover; ‘Roles and responsibilities of medical and midwifery staff working within the maternity services'. Register number 04227; point 4.0
The handover of care takes place on the Labour Ward between 08.30 – 09.00 hours using the ‘white board' in the Labour Ward office.
The handover of care should include the following professionals:
Obstetric Consultant
Obstetric Registrar
Obstetric SHO
Labour Ward Coordinator
Labour Ward Anaesthetist
Consultant Anaesthetist Monday – Friday
Out of hours, the handover of care should be between same professionals at each shift change, and between obstetric and anaesthetic staff.
The purpose of the handover is to provide the opportunity to:
Provide information on the patients on the ward and review their plan of care
Identify any patient with high risk factors that could potentially present with complications during the shift

To inform all health care professionals of any patients, either obstetric or gynaecological, receiving care in Broomfield Hospital and of any patients whom may have required transfer to a tertiary centre. Obstetric patients will be recorded on the white board
Identify high risk antenatal/postnatal patients on the postnatal ward or on antenatal ward / day assessment unit who require a review
Discuss any incidences from the previous shift
In addition to this handover, the Obstetric Consultant responsible for the Labour Ward should:
Conduct a physical ward round as a minimum, at least once a day after the morning staff change over. This includes out of hours at the weekends and on Bank Holidays

Conduct a telephone ward round with the Obstetric Registrar on duty at 22:00 hours providing an opportunity to identify any patient with high risk factors that could potentially present with complications during the remainder of the shift (on call consultant)
The Obstetric Specialist Registrar (SPR)
Handover of care and the on-call bleep should take place on the Labour Ward during the shift handover at 08.00 hours and 20.00 hours.
For the purpose of the handover, refer to the Guideline for roles and responsibilities of medical and midwifery staff working within the maternity services'; register number 04227; points 4.3.
Senior House Officers (SHO)
Handover of care and the on-call bleep should take place on the Labour Ward during the shift handover at 08.00 hours and 20.00 hours.
For the purpose of the handover, refer to the Guideline for roles and responsibilities of medical and midwifery staff working within the maternity services'; register number 04227; points 4.4.
Locum Doctors or Agency Staff
(Refer to the ‘Guideline for roles and responsibilities of medical and midwifery staff working within the maternity services'. Register number 04227; point 7.0
Refer to ‘Mandatory training for Maternity Services'; register number 09062)

For medical staff, the SPR or consultant responsible for the Labour Ward at the commencement of the first shift or the Labour Ward Co-ordinator for midwives should ensure completion of the agency and locum local induction checklist.
The completed Induction Programme Checklist for Bank/Agency midwives should be filed in the appropriate folder kept in the Labour Ward Handover Room.
The completed proforma entitled ‘Essential information for Locum Doctors should be returned by the Locum doctor at the end of the shift to Medical resources (B244)/ Clinical Operations Centre (A202).
The locum or agency staff should be orientated to all the relevant clinical areas.
Where there is a locum, he or she will receive a personal handover from the obstetric registrar or SHO as appropriate as for point 5.0.
Handover of Care on Labour Ward
(Refer to the Guideline for roles and responsibilities of medical and midwifery staff working within the maternity services'; register number 04227)
The Labour Ward midwifery shift handover is the responsibility of the Labour Ward Co- ordinator. It is carried out at 08:00 and 20:00 hours from the white board in the Labour Ward office.

The handover is led by the Labour Ward Co-ordinator on the previous shift to all staff on the shift change. The Obstetric Registrar should also be present to support Labour Ward Co-ordinator with additional handover information if required.
An additional handover will be undertaken if there are midwifery staff allocated to a late shift which will be at 14:00 hours.

The handover of care should include not only the inpatients on the ward, but expected admissions, the number of inductions of labour – both ongoing and for admission, elective caesarean sections, status of the Neonatal Unit if changed from the previous shift and bed status within the consultant unit.

There is an additional personal face-to-face handover of care between the midwife assuming the care of the patient and the midwife relinquishing responsibility of care. This will usually be carried out in the presence of the patient enabling a clear understanding of her care and management. This face-to-face handover should be documented in the patient's health care records.
Handover of Care when Transferring Patients from the Labour Ward to the Postnatal Ward
(Refer to ‘Routine postnatal care for mothers and their babies'. Register number 09127)
The postnatal healthcare records should be completed prior to the transfer.

A midwife transfer and personal face to face handover from Labour Ward to the Postnatal Ward should be carried out and documented in the patient's maternity health care records, unless conditions prevent this i.e. busy periods. In this situation the midwife is required to document a retrospective entry. Records should always be written contemporaneously or as soon as possible after the events described, prior to the midwife's documentation of events to identify this entry as ‘written in retrospect'. (Maternity record keeping including documentation in the handheld records; register number 06036)

If a personal face to face handover is not possible at the time of transfer, there should be a midwife to midwife verbal handover via the telephone, followed by a face to face handover as soon as it is possible. In this circumstance, the transfer should be made with a maternity care assistant.
Under no circumstances, should birth partners or relatives transfer patients.

The Postnatal Care Record should be completed by the midwife receiving the patient from the Labour Ward and both the midwife handing over the care and the midwife receiving the woman should sign the handover of care page.
The relevant antenatal, intrapartum and immediate postnatal factors to be identified
Identification of the professional responsible for care of the mother and her baby
Care planning for the postnatal period
Anticipated length of stay
Identification of the involvement of specialist health care professionals / agencies
Handover of Care when Transferring from the Antenatal Ward/ Day Assessment (DAU) to the Labour Ward
A midwife transfer and personal face to face handover from the Antenatal Ward/DAU to the Labour Ward should be carried out and documented in the patient's maternity health care records.
Under no circumstances, should birth partners or relatives transfer patients.
The SBAR handover tool should be completed by the midwife receiving the handover to enable:
Identification of relevant factors from the antenatal period.
Identification of the professional responsible for care of the patient
Progress of labour
Plans for labour and delivery (see Birth Plan)
Handover of Care when Transferring from the Consultant Unit to the Midwife-led Units
It is reasonable for a verbal handover of care via the telephone as, in this circumstance it is not possible to have a personal face to face handover of care due to the location of the units.
During the handover, the midwife in the midwife-led unit should complete the SBAR tool as for point 3.4.
In addition, the postnatal health care records should be completed prior to the transfer.
Handover of Care when Transferring from the Consultant Unit to Home
(Refer to Guideline for routine postnatal care of mothers and their babies'; register number 09127)

When patients are discharged home from the Consultant Unit to community care, the discharge book on the Postnatal Ward should be completed. For those patients outside of Chelmsford community, the relevant hospital should be informed of the discharge, providing the relevant information as documented in the discharge book.
Handover of Care to ITU
(Refer to the ‘Assist medical and midwifery staff in the provision of high dependency care and arrangements for safe and timely transfer to ITU'; register number 04232)
Documentation

Documentation should be in accordance with this guideline and in conjunction with the ‘Guideline for maternity record keeping including documentation in handheld records guideline for record keeping'; register number 06036 .

There is no requirement for the doctors to document a handover of care as described in the ‘Guideline for roles and responsibilities of medical and midwifery staff working within the maternity services'; register number 04227; points 4.4. However, if a review of a patient is required from the handover of care, the doctor should document the review and the plan of care clearly in the health care records.
Staffing and Training
All midwifery and obstetric staff must attend yearly mandatory training which includes record keeping and documentation.
All midwifery and obstetric staff are to ensure that their knowledge and skills are up-to-date in order to complete their portfolio for appraisal.
Professional Midwifery Advocates

Professional Midwifery Advocates provide a mechanism of support and guidance to women and midwives. Professional Midwifery Advocates are experienced practising midwives who have undertaken further education in order to supervise midwifery services and to advise and support midwives and women in their care choices.
Infection Prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention by ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after each procedure.
Audit and Monitoring

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy and the Maternity annual audit work plan. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.
As a minimum the following specific requirements will be monitored:

Locally or nationally developed tools to ensure a consistent approach to the documentation of the handover of care, for example Situation Background Assessment and Recommendation (SBAR) or Reason Story Vital Signs and Plan (RSVP)
Handover at the change of shift, for each staff group, to include both giving and receiving of information
Handover for transfer between care settings, to include both giving and receiving of information
Documentation of handover between all care settings
Process for audit, multidisciplinary review of results and subsequent monitoring of action plans

A review of a suitable sample of health records of patients to include the minimum requirements as highlighted in point  will be audited. A minimum compliance 75% is required for each requirement. Where concerns are identified more frequent audit will be undertaken.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.

The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group report will be reported to the Directorate Governance Meeting on a quarterly basis and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Patient Quality and Safety Committee (PSQC) within the Chief Nurse report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Guideline Management

As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.

Quarterly memos are sent to line managers to disseminate to their staff the most currently approved guidelines available via the intranet and clinical guideline folders, located in each designated clinical area.

Guideline monitors have been nominated to each clinical area to ensure a system whereby obsolete guidelines are archived and newly approved guidelines are now downloaded from the intranet and filed appropriately in the guideline folders. ‘Spot checks' are performed on all clinical guidelines quarterly.

Quarterly Clinical Practices group meetings are held to discuss ‘guidelines'. During this meeting the practice development midwife can highlight any areas for future training needs will be met using methods such as ‘workshops' or to be included in future ‘skills and drills' mandatory training sessions.
Communication

A quarterly ‘maternity newsletter' is issued to all staff to highlight key changes in clinical practice to include a list of newly approved guidelines for staff to acknowledge and familiarise themselves with and practice accordingly. Midwives that are on maternity
leave or ‘bank' staff have letters sent to their home address to update them on current clinical changes.
Approved guidelines are published monthly in the Trust's Staff Focus that is sent via email to all staff.
Approved guidelines will be disseminated to appropriate staff quarterly via email.

Regular memos are posted on the guideline and audit notice boards in each clinical area to notify staff of the latest revised guidelines and how to access guidelines via the intranet or clinical guideline folders.
References
Ottewill M, Urben J, Elson E (2007) Safe handover: Safe care. Midwives RCM December Volume 10 No 11
Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists (2016) Providing quality care for
